name: Teaching Guide: Exploring Women and the Temperance Movement

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Describe how the [illustration from *Temperance Torchlights*](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1775), “[Intemperance and Cholera](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1780),” the cartoon “[A Model School Among the Germans](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1781),” and the [article from the *Los Angeles Voice*](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1787) portray the dangers of drinking. What arguments do these sources make for temperance or abstinence, and what evidence do they provide for support?
2. Other than refraining from drinking alcohol, what values did the Temperance Movement support? Choose three primary sources and use them to identify these values. 
3. Use [Lyman Beecher’s sermon](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1774), [Dio Lewis’s biography](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1776), the [illustration of the temperance meeting](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1779), and [Frances Willard’s address](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1783) to compare men’s and women’s roles in promoting temperance.
4. Look at the [illustration from *Sweet Cicely*](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1778) and the [advertisement for the Keeley Institute](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1788). Analyze how they portray women promoting temperance. Next, compare the image and the ad with how the [photograph of Carrie Nation](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1785) portrays the well-known temperance crusader.
5. Many believed that it was women’s Christian duty to crusade for temperance. Use the appeal women crusaders presented to liquor sellers of Fredonia in [Dio Lewis’s biography](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1776) to explain how they combined faith with femininity.
6. Consider that many women who participated in the Temperance Movement also were involved with other social causes. Use [Frances Willard’s address](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1783) and “[Temperance Arithmetic](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1782)” to identify the movements and interests that overlapped with the Temperance Movement and its supporters.

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text:
1. Ask students to use the following primary sources to identify the different strategies women used to advocate for temperance: the [illustration from *Sweet Cicely*](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1778), [Dio Lewis’s biography](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1776), [Frances Willard’s address](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1783), and the photograph of [Carrie Nation’s “hatchetation” of the saloon in Kansas](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1786). Next, divide students into groups. Each team will argue for the temperance strategy they find most effective, drawing on evidence from the primary sources above.
2. Ask students to research black women’s involvement in the Temperance Movement and Ida B. Wells. Next, they should research the Willard/Wells dispute described in [Frances Willard’s letter to Albion Tourgée](https://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1784), then hypothesize about the opportunities and obstacles black women faced in campaigning for temperance and other causes. After looking again at Frances Willard’s letter, each student should write a letter from Ida B. Wells to Frances Willard that responds to the statement that Willard has been characterized unfairly “as the enemy of a race that I love and on whose behalf I would do anything.”
